lines.value: MARULLUS
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?

lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels?
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: To towers and windows, yea, to chimney-tops,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Your infants in your arms, and there have sat
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: The livelong day, with patient expectation,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome:
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: And when you saw his chariot but appear,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Have you not made an universal shout,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: That Tiber trembled underneath her banks,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: To hear the replication of your sounds
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Made in her concave shores?
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: And do you now put on your best attire?
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: And do you now cull out a holiday?
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,
lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.speaker: MARULLUS

lines.value: FLAVIUS
lines.speaker: FLAVIUS

lines.speaker: FLAVIUS

lines.speaker: FLAVIUS

lines.speaker: FLAVIUS

lines.speaker: FLAVIUS

lines.value: Calpurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: As we have seen him in the Capitol,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Being cross'd in conference by some senators.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Casca will tell us what the matter is.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Antonius!
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: ANTONY
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: Caesar?
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Let me have men about me that are fat;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: ANTONY
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: He is a noble Roman and well given.
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Yet if my name were liable to fear,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I do not know the man I should avoid
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: He is a great observer and he looks
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: That could be moved to smile at any thing.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Such men as he be never at heart's ease
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And therefore are they very dangerous.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Ay, Casca; tell us what hath chanced to-day,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: That Caesar looks so sad.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Why, you were with him, were you not?
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Why, there was a crown offered him: and being
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: What was the second noise for?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Why, for that too.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Why, for that too.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Was the crown offered him thrice?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: time gentler than other, and at every putting-by
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: mine honest neighbours shouted.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Who offered him the crown?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Why, Antony.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: neither, 'twas one of these coronets;--and, as I told
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: offered it to him again; then he put it by again:
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: fingers off it. And then he offered it the third
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: time; he put it the third time by: and still as he
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: But, soft, I pray you: what, did Caesar swound?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: He fell down in the market-place, and foamed at
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: mouth, and was speechless.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: 'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: I know not what you mean by that; but, I am sure,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: displeased them, as they use to do the players in
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: the theatre, I am no true man.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: What said he when he came unto himself?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: common herd was glad he refused the crown, he
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: throat to cut. An I had been a man of any
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: he fell. When he came to himself again, he said,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: If he had done or said any thing amiss, he desired
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: or four wenches, where I stood, cried 'Alas, good
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: And after that, he came, thus sad, away?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Ay.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Did Cicero say any thing?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Ay, he spoke Greek.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: To what effect?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Nay, an I tell you that, Ill ne'er look you i' the
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: face again: but those that understood him smiled at
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: one another and shook their heads; but, for mine own
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: off Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: well. There was more foolery yet, if I could
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: remember it.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Will you sup with me to-night, Casca?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: No, I am promised forth.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Will you dine with me to-morrow?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: worth the eating.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Good: I will expect you.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Do so. Farewell, both.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: He was quick mettle when he went to school.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: So is he now in execution
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Of any bold or noble enterprise,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: However he puts on this tardy form.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Which gives men stomach to digest his words
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: With better appetite.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: And so it is. For this time I will leave you:
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: To-morrow, if you please to speak with me,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: I will come home to you; or, if you will,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Come home to me, and I will wait for you.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: I will do so: till then, think of the world.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I see,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Thy honourable metal may be wrought
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: From that it is disposed: therefore it is meet
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That noble minds keep ever with their likes;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: For who so firm that cannot be seduced?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Caesar doth bear me hard; but he loves Brutus:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: He should not humour me. I will this night,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: In several hands, in at his windows throw,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: As if they came from several citizens,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Writings all tending to the great opinion
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That Rome holds of his name; wherein obscurely
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And after this let Caesar seat him sure;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: For we will shake him, or worse days endure.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CICERO
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home?
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: To be exalted with the threatening clouds:
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: But never till to-night, never till now,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Either there is a civil strife in heaven,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Incenses them to send destruction.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CICERO
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: A common slave--you know him well by sight--
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Not sensible of fire, remain'd unscorch'd.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Against the Capitol I met a lion,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Who glared upon me, and went surly by,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Without annoying me: and there were drawn
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Transformed with their fear; who swore they saw
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: And yesterday the bird of night did sit
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Even at noon-day upon the market-place,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Do so conjointly meet, let not men say
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: 'These are their reasons; they are natural;'
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: For, I believe, they are portentous things
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Unto the climate that they point upon.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CICERO
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time:
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: But men may construe things after their fashion,
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow?
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: He doth; for he did bid Antonius
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Send word to you he would be there to-morrow.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CICERO
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Good night then, Casca: this disturbed sky
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: Is not to walk in.
lines.speaker: CICERO

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Farewell, Cicero.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Who's there?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: A Roman.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Casca, by your voice.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: A very pleasing night to honest men.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Submitting me unto the perilous night,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: The breast of heaven, I did present myself
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Even in the aim and very flash of it.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: It is the part of men to fear and tremble,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: When the most mighty gods by tokens send
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That should be in a Roman you do want,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: To see the strange impatience of the heavens:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: But if you would consider the true cause
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Why old men fool and children calculate,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Why all these things change from their ordinance
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Their natures and preformed faculties
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: To monstrous quality,--why, you shall find
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That heaven hath infused them with these spirits,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: To make them instruments of fear and warning
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Unto some monstrous state.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Most like this dreadful night,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: As doth the lion in the Capitol,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: A man no mightier than thyself or me
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: In personal action, yet prodigious grown
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: 'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Let it be who it is: for Romans now
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Mean to establish Caesar as a king;
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: In every place, save here in Italy.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: I know where I will wear this dagger then;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: But life, being weary of these worldly bars,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: If I know this, know all the world besides,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: That part of tyranny that I do bear
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: I can shake off at pleasure.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: So can I:
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: So every bondman in his own hand bears
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: The power to cancel his captivity.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: But that he sees the Romans are but sheep:
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: He were no lion, were not Romans hinds.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Begin it with weak straws: what trash is Rome,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: What rubbish and what offal, when it serves
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: For the base matter to illuminate
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Before a willing bondman; then I know
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: My answer must be made. But I am arm'd,
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And dangers are to me indifferent.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: CASCA
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: You speak to Casca, and to such a man
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold, my hand:
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: Be factious for redress of all these griefs,
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: And I will set this foot of mine as far
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: As who goes farthest.
lines.speaker: CASCA

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: There's a bargain made.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: To undergo with me an enterprise
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Of honourable-dangerous consequence;

lines.value: More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof,

lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: But when he once attains the upmost round.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.

lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: For I can give his humour the true bent,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: And I will bring him to the Capitol.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CINNA
lines.speaker: CINNA

lines.value: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.
lines.speaker: CINNA

lines.value: METELLUS CIMBER
lines.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER

lines.value: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,
lines.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER

lines.value: Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey:
lines.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER

lines.value: I wonder none of you have thought of him.
lines.speaker: METELLUS CIMBER

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Now, good Metellus, go along by him:
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CASSIUS
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you, Brutus.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.
lines.speaker: CASSIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Let not our looks put on our purposes,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: But bear it as our Roman actors do,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: With untired spirits and formal constancy:
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: And so good morrow to you every one.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Which busy care draws in the brains of men;
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Brutus, my lord!
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Portia, what mean you? wherefore rise you now?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: It is not for your health thus to commit
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Stole from my bed: and yesternight, at supper,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: You suddenly arose, and walk'd about,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Musing and sighing, with your arms across,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And when I ask'd you what the matter was,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: You stared upon me with ungentle looks;
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot;
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: But, with an angry wafture of your hand,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Gave sign for me to leave you: so I did;
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Fearing to strengthen that impatience
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Hoping it was but an effect of humour,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Which sometime hath his hour with every man.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And could it work so much upon your shape
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: As it hath much prevail'd on your condition,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: I am not well in health, and that is all.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: He would embrace the means to come by it.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Is Brutus sick? and is it physical
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: To walk unbraced and suck up the humours
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: To dare the vile contagion of the night
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus;
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: You have some sick offence within your mind,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Which, by the right and virtue of my place,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I ought to know of: and, upon my knees,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: By all your vows of love and that great vow
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Which did incorporate and make us one,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: That you unfold to me, yourself, your half,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Why you are heavy, and what men to-night
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Have had to resort to you: for here have been
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Some six or seven, who did hide their faces
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Even from darkness.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Kneel not, gentle Portia.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Is it excepted I should know no secrets
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: That appertain to you? Am I yourself
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: But, as it were, in sort or limitation,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: You are my true and honourable wife,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: As dear to me as are the ruddy drops
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: That visit my sad heart
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: PORTIA
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: If this were true, then should I know this secret.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I grant I am a woman; but withal
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I grant I am a woman; but withal
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Think you I am no stronger than my sex,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Being so father'd and so husbanded?
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em:
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: I have made strong proof of my constancy,
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Giving myself a voluntary wound
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience.
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: And not my husband's secrets?
lines.speaker: PORTIA

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: O ye gods,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Render me worthy of this noble wife!
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Hark, hark! one knocks: Portia, go in awhile;
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: And by and by thy bosom shall partake
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: The secrets of my heart.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: All my engagements I will construe to thee,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: All the charactery of my sad brows:
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Leave me with haste.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Lucius, who's that knocks?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LUCIUS
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: He is a sick man that would speak with you.
lines.speaker: LUCIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! how?
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LIGARIUS
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LIGARIUS
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Any exploit worthy the name of honour.
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LIGARIUS
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: By all the gods that Romans bow before,
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome!
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Brave son, derived from honourable loins!
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: My mortified spirit. Now bid me run,
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: And I will strive with things impossible;
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LIGARIUS
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: But are not some whole that we must make sick?
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: That must we also. What it is, my Caius,
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: I shall unfold to thee, as we are going
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: To whom it must be done.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: LIGARIUS
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: Set on your foot,
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: And with a heart new-fired I follow you,
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: To do I know not what: but it sufficeth
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: That Brutus leads me on.
lines.speaker: LIGARIUS

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Follow me, then.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: 'Help, ho! they murder Caesar!' Who's within?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Servant
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: My lord?
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And bring me their opinions of success.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Servant
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: I will, my lord.
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: CALPURNIA
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: What mean you, Caesar? think you to walk forth?
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: You shall not stir out of your house to-day.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: The face of Caesar, they are vanished.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: CALPURNIA
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Yet now they fright me. There is one within,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: A lioness hath whelped in the streets;
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead;
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol;
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: The noise of battle hurtled in the air,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: O Caesar! these things are beyond all use,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: And I do fear them.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: What can be avoided
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: CALPURNIA
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: When beggars die, there are no comets seen;
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Cowards die many times before their deaths;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: The valiant never taste of death but once.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: It seems to me most strange that men should fear;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Seeing that death, a necessary end,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Will come when it will come.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: What say the augurers?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Servant
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: They would not have you to stir forth to-day.
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: They could not find a heart within the beast.
lines.speaker: Servant

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: The gods do this in shame of cowardice:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Caesar should be a beast without a heart,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: If he should stay at home to-day for fear.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: No, Caesar shall not: danger knows full well
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: That Caesar is more dangerous than he:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: We are two lions litter'd in one day,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And I the elder and more terrible:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And Caesar shall go forth.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: CALPURNIA
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Alas, my lord,
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Do not go forth to-day: call it my fear
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: We'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house:
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: And he shall say you are not well to-day:
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Mark Antony shall say I am not well,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And, for thy humour, I will stay at home.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Caesar, all hail! good morrow, worthy Caesar:
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: I come to fetch you to the senate-house.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And you are come in very happy time,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: To bear my greeting to the senators
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And tell them that I will not come to-day:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I will not come to-day: tell them so, Decius.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: CALPURNIA
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: Say he is sick.
lines.speaker: CALPURNIA

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Shall Caesar send a lie?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: The cause is in my will: I will not come;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: That is enough to satisfy the senate.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: But for your private satisfaction,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Because I love you, I will let you know:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: She dreamt to-night she saw my statua,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Did run pure blood: and many lusty Romans
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And these does she apply for warnings, and portents,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And evils imminent; and on her knee
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: This dream is all amiss interpreted;
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: It was a vision fair and fortunate:
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: In which so many smiling Romans bathed,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Reviving blood, and that great men shall press
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: For tinctures, stains, relics and cognizance.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And this way have you well expounded it.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: DECIUS BRUTUS
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: I have, when you have heard what I can say:
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: And know it now: the senate have concluded
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: If you shall send them word you will not come,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Apt to be render'd, for some one to say
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: 'Break up the senate till another time,
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.'
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: 'Lo, Caesar is afraid'?
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: To our proceeding bids me tell you this;
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: And reason to my love is liable.
lines.speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I am ashamed I did yield to them.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Give me my robe, for I will go.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: And look where Publius is come to fetch me.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: PUBLIUS
lines.speaker: PUBLIUS

lines.value: Good morrow, Caesar.
lines.speaker: PUBLIUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Welcome, Publius.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: As that same ague which hath made you lean.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: What is 't o'clock?
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: BRUTUS
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.
lines.speaker: BRUTUS

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: See! Antony, that revels long o' nights,
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: ANTONY
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: So to most noble Caesar.
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: CAESAR
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Bid them prepare within:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I am to blame to be thus waited for.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Now, Cinna: now, Metellus: what, Trebonius!
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: I have an hour's talk in store for you;
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Remember that you call on me to-day:
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: Be near me, that I may remember you.
lines.speaker: CAESAR

lines.value: TREBONIUS

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: Than I will wrong such honourable men.
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;
lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.speaker: ANTONY

lines.value: Unto their issue.

lines.value: LUCILIUS
